questions.title: Array Time Complexity
questions.content: What is the time complexity of accessing an element in an array by index?

questions.title: Array Memory Layout
questions.content: How are array elements stored in memory?

questions.title: Array Properties
questions.content: Which of the following are true about arrays?

mcq_options.text: Elements are stored in contiguous memory
All elements must be of the same data type

questions.title: Find Maximum Element
questions.content: Write a function to find the maximum element in an array of integers.
questions.outputFormat: An integer representing the maximum element.

questions.title: Array Insertion Complexity
questions.content: What is the worst-case time complexity for inserting an element at the beginning of an array?

questions.title: Array Rotation
questions.content: Given an integer array nums, rotate the array to the right by k steps, where k is non-negative.

examples.explanation:
rotate 1 steps to the right: [7,1,2,3,4,5,6]
rotate 2 steps to the right: [6,7,1,2,3,4,5]
rotate 3 steps to the right: [5,6,7,1,2,3,4]

rotate 1 steps to the right: [99,-1,-100,3]
rotate 2 steps to the right: [3,99,-1,-100]

questions.inputFormat:
The first line contains the array `nums`.
The second line contains the integer `k`.

questions.title: Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array
questions.content: Given an integer array nums sorted in non-decreasing order, remove the duplicates in-place such that each unique element appears only once. The relative order of the elements should be kept the same. Then return the number of unique elements in nums.

examples.explanation: Your function should return k = 2, with the first two elements of nums being 1 and 2 respectively.
Your function should return k = 5, with the first five elements of nums being 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 respectively.

questions.inputFormat: An integer array `nums` sorted in non-decreasing order.
questions.outputFormat: An integer k representing the number of unique elements.

questions.title: String Immutability
questions.content: In most programming languages (like Java and Python), strings are immutable. What does this mean?

mcq_options.text: Once created, their content cannot be changed.
They cannot be assigned to a new variable.

questions.title: Reverse String
questions.content: Write a function that reverses a string. The input string is given as an array of characters.

questions.title: Valid Anagram
questions.content: Given two strings s and t, return true if t is an anagram of s, and false otherwise. An Anagram is a word or phrase formed by rearranging the letters of a different word or phrase, typically using all the original letters exactly once.
questions.inputFormat: Two strings `s` and `t` on separate lines.
questions.outputFormat: `true` if `t` is an anagram of `s`, otherwise `false`.

questions.title: Two Sum
questions.content: Given an array of integers nums and an integer target, return indices of the two numbers such that they add up to target. You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice. You can return the answer in any order.
questions.inputFormat:
The first line contains the array `nums`.
The second line contains the integer `target`.
questions.outputFormat: An array containing the two indices.

questions.title: Container With Most Water
questions.content: You are given an integer array height of length n. There are n vertical lines drawn such that the two endpoints of the ith line are (i, 0) and (i, height[i]). Find two lines that together with the x-axis form a container, such that the container contains the most water. Return the maximum amount of water a container can store. Notice that you may not slant the container.

examples.explanation: The above vertical lines are represented by array [1,8,6,2,5,4,8,3,7]. In this case, the max area of water (blue section) the container can contain is 49.

questions.outputFormat: An integer representing the maximum water.

questions.title: Linked List Node Structure
questions.content: What does a typical singly linked list node contain?

mcq_options.text: Data and pointer to next node

questions.title: Insert at Beginning of Linked List
questions.content: Given the head of a singly linked list and an integer `val`, insert a new node with value `val` at the beginning of the list and return the new head.
questions.inputFormat:
The first line contains the linked list `head` as an array.
The second line contains the integer `val`.
questions.outputFormat: The new linked list as an array.

questions.title: Delete Node in a Linked List
questions.content: There is a singly-linked list head and we want to delete a node node in it. You are given the node to be deleted. You will not be given access to the first node of head. All the values of the linked list are unique, and it is guaranteed that the given node node is not the last node in the linked list.

examples.explanation: You are given the second node with value 5, the linked list should become 4 -> 1 -> 9 after calling your function.
You are given the third node with value 1, the linked list should become 4 -> 5 -> 9 after calling your function.

questions.inputFormat: The linked list `head` and value `node` to delete. (Note: standard input format depends on judge, here assuming value based)
questions.outputFormat: The modified linked list found by traversing from head.

questions.title: Doubly Linked List Advantage
questions.content: What is the main advantage of doubly linked lists over singly linked lists?

questions.title: Design Linked List
questions.content: Design your implementation of the linked list. You can choose to use a singly or doubly linked list. A node in a singly linked list should have two attributes: val and next. val is the value of the current node, and next is a pointer/reference to the next node. If you want to use the doubly linked list, you will need one more attribute prev to indicate the previous node in the linked list. Assume all nodes in the linked list are 0-indexed.
questions.inputFormat: A list of method calls and their arguments.

questions.title: Reverse Linked List
questions.content: Given the head of a singly linked list, reverse the list, and return the reversed list.
questions.inputFormat: The linked list `head` as an array.
questions.outputFormat: The reversed linked list as an array.

questions.title: Linked List Cycle
questions.content: Given head, the head of a linked list, determine if the linked list has a cycle in it. There is a cycle in a linked list if there is some node in the list that can be reached again by continuously following the next pointer. Internally, pos is used to denote the index of the node that tail's next pointer is connected to. Note that pos is not passed as a parameter.

examples.explanation: There is a cycle in the linked list, where the tail connects to the 1st node (0-indexed).
There is a cycle in the linked list, where the tail connects to the 0th node.

questions.outputFormat: `true` if there is a cycle, otherwise `false`.

questions.title: Merge Two Sorted Lists
questions.content: You are given the heads of two sorted linked lists list1 and list2. Merge the two lists into one sorted list. The list should be made by splicing together the nodes of the first two lists. Return the head of the merged linked list.
questions.inputFormat: Two arrays `list1` and `list2` representing the sorted linked lists.
questions.outputFormat: The merged sorted linked list as an array.

questions.title: Binary Tree Properties
questions.content: What is the maximum number of nodes at level k in a binary tree (root is at level 0)?

questions.title: Binary Tree Inorder Traversal
questions.content: Implement inorder traversal of a binary tree both recursively and iteratively.

questions.title: Binary Tree Level Order Traversal
questions.content: Given a binary tree, return the level order traversal of its nodes' values.

questions.title: BST Search Complexity
questions.content: What is the average time complexity for searching in a balanced BST?

questions.title: Validate Binary Search Tree
questions.content: Write a function to validate if a binary tree is a valid binary search tree.

questions.title: Insert into BST
questions.content: Insert a given value into a Binary Search Tree and return the root of the modified tree.

questions.title: Graph Representation
questions.content: Which are common ways to represent a graph in memory?

questions.title: Graph BFS Implementation
questions.content: Implement breadth-first search (BFS) traversal for a graph represented as an adjacency list.

questions.title: Graph DFS Implementation
questions.content: Implement depth-first search (DFS) traversal for a graph using both recursive and iterative approaches.

questions.title: Number of Islands
questions.content: Given a 2D binary grid which represents a map of '1's (land) and '0's (water), return the number of islands.

examples.explanation: There is only one island (connected group of 1s).
There are three islands: one at top-left, one in the middle, and one at bottom-right.

questions.outputFormat: An integer representing the number of islands.

questions.title: Course Schedule
questions.content: There are a total of numCourses courses you have to take, labeled from 0 to numCourses - 1. You are given an array prerequisites where prerequisites[i] = [ai, bi] indicates that you must take course bi first if you want to take course ai. Return true if you can finish all courses.

examples.explanation: There are a total of 2 courses to take. To take course 1 you should have finished course 0. So it is possible.
There are a total of 2 courses to take. To take course 1 you should have finished course 0, and to take course 0 you should also have finished course 1. So it is impossible.

questions.outputFormat: `true` if it is possible to finish all courses, otherwise `false`.

questions.title: Algorithm Complexity
questions.content: What does Big O notation describe?

mcq_options.text: Upper bound of algorithm's time complexity
Lower bound of algorithm's time complexity

questions.title: Implement Binary Search
questions.content: Given an array of integers nums which is sorted in ascending order, and an integer target, write a function to search target in nums. If target exists, then return its index. Otherwise, return -1. You must write an algorithm with O(log n) runtime complexity.

examples.explanation: 9 exists in nums and its index is 4
2 does not exist in nums so return -1

questions.inputFormat: A sorted integer array `nums` and an integer `target`.
questions.outputFormat: The index of `target` in `nums`, or -1 if not found.
